Cotillion Board

Seven Jobs Open
The seven positions open are
president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and three representatives to the Student Council
from each class.
The only requirement for holding a class office is that the candidate must be a member of that
particular class. The Student
Council president must be a member of next year's senior class.
Number of Names
Petitions for the nomination of
officers for next year's sophomore
class and those for the future junior class must contain 40 signatures.
Future seniors must have a total
of 45 signatures before nomination
will be considered. The candidacy
for president of the Student Council requires 85 names.
Must Belong —
No student may sign a petition
concerning any class other than his
own, with the exception, of course,
of the petitions of those candidates
for president of the SC. •
Completely signed
petitions
should be turned in to the Student
Council box, number 1246, on or
before 4 pm, Monday, April 25.
Candidates will then be announced
and the elections will be called.

Undergraduates
Give Bowman Gift
Undergraduates will present a
mahogany electric clock to President Emeritus Isaiah Bowman.
The gift, sponsored by class
presidents, is a Seth Thomas
mantlepiece. Further plans will
be announced in the class meetings, all of which will take place
next Friday at 10 am.
Sophomores will meet in Merganthaler 111 to discuss Class Day
and the class weekend. Seniors'
meeting, to be held in an as yet
undisclosed place, will be concerned with Class Day and a financial
report from the 49ar dance.
Freshmen will meet in Remsen
1 to discuss Class Day and coming plans, while the juniors will
discuss spring functions and Class
day in the Great hall of Levering.

New Magazine In
Hopkins Library
Something new in the way or
magazines, called Our Nation's'
Heritage will be displayed this
week in the main reading room
of the Johns Hopkins University
Library.
The magazine, a gift of Charles
Garland of the University Board
of Trustees, will be published in
book form six times a year.
Abounding in colorful pictures
and first rate photography attempts to present "the American
way of life" in a pictorial manner.
The publication, according to the
publishers, the B C Forbes Company, is trying to convey "in a
dramatic, graphic way a wider
knowledge of all the elements
which have made and make our
nation; to give a picture of the
heritage .. . in a manner that will
have the greatest appeal to the
most Americans."

NEWS-LETTER

Price Day Speaks Before
_MC On British Empire

Third Sedar

Price Day, informal and reserved, the author of a series of
articles in The Sun on modern
imperialism and field correspondent during World War II, was
guest speaker at the International
Relations Club last Friday.
In his discussion of the changing British Empire, Mr Day began with the Indian situation.
He observed that India, though
a constitutional republic with no
allegiance to the Crown, still
wishes to remain in some association with the Commonwealth. And
Britain necessarily wishes to retain connections with India.
Has Been Burden
India, Mr Day mentioned, had
been an economic burden for years,
but from the security point of
view Britain's loss had been "terrific." From the political standpoint, now, India has the potential
power to lead an entire Southern
Asiatic bloc.
Britain must now set up some
formal relationship with its dominions. This, explained Mr Day,
reflects a change in Britain's imperial status.
Australia Industrializing
Australia, he continued, is industrializing, with hopes toward
establishing large trade areas in
, Asia. This immediately changes
the mercantile position of Britain
which previously functioned as
the middle man for Australian resources.
New Zealand, on the other hand,
Is the "closest" to her mother
country in the sense of exports.

Easter Habit!

... for many an Easter, college
men have favored the fine fit
and good looks of

the telephone in her
house a real work-out.
But we're not worried a bit. We know
Mary Jane's telephone is going to keep right
on delivering good service year after year.
Because the Bell System puts a lot of time,
thought, and testing into making telephone
equipment as rugged and trouble-free as
possible.
Tests are constantly under way at the
Bell Telephone Laboratories. There, for
example, new types of telephone instruments are put through a school of hard
knocks. Dials and other parts are given
strength and wear tests. Even the bottom
of the telephone set has been designed
and checked to make sure that it will not
scratch or stain furniture.
Such tests—on little things as well as on
big things—help give you the world's best
telephone service at the lowest possible
cost.

Fitting Climax. Found
In Verdi's Requiem
Last week's Spring Music Festival, given under the auspices of
the Baltimore Institute of Musical
Arts, found an eminently fitting
climax in the presentation of
Verdi's Requiem Mass. The work
was performed last Sunday at the
Baltimore Polytechnic Institute
under the direction of Hugo Weisgall.
It is easy to imagine how this
turbulent music might have become a vehicle for the kind of dramatic showmanship which has upon occasion been witnessed in the
case of far less worthy music at
the Lyric. But last Sunday soloists, chorus, orchestra and conductor put heart and soul and no
little ability into as stirring a
choral composition as has ever
been written.
It is to be hoped that last week's
successful enterprise will see
repetition in the years to come.

The News-Letter editor has requested me to criticise this show.
What am I to say? The editor has
placed me in the same position
that I placed Ruth when I asked
my inane question about the use
of red. I have no universals to
which I may turn, no valid books
to read stating how a work of art
should be executed. I do know,
however, what I like in the show.
Objects which I like I consider
good, and are considered good
simply because they have given
me a feeling of pleasure. Therefore I say that which gives me
pleasure is a work of art, be it
products from a cuisine, the results of concuipisence, or, in the
present instance, creations with
pigment, pencil, ink, or plastic material.
I employ the term, "work of
art", in a thoroughly subjective
manner. That which does not give
me pleasure is not a work of art.
To someone else, yes, perhaps,
it is; but that doesn't interest- me.
Apparently no particular technique was singled out by the
udges of the current show. Abract artists and realistic artists
hd entries accepted. In fact I
shuld say that ever recognizable
art", form in the various media
specified was represented. Superficially one might say that this was
the result of the criticism from
last year's show, a show which was
heavy with expressionism and surrealism. I don't think that this
s true. The judges only expressed catholicity of taste—a human
atstribute which too many persons
attempt to negate. Of the ninetythree accepted entries, I liked the
following:

Seven Jobs Open
The seven positions open are
president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and three representatives to the Student Council
from each class.
The only requirement for holding a class office is that the candidate must be a member of that
particular class. The Student
Council president must be a member of next year's senior class.
Number of Names
Petitions for the nomination of
officers for next year's sophomore
class and those for the future junior class must contain 40 signatures.
Future seniors must have a total
of 45 signatures before nomination
will be considered. The candidacy
for president of the Student Council requires 85 names.
Must Belong —
No student may sign a petition
concerning any class other than his
own, with the exception, of course,
of the petitions of those candidates
for president of the SC. •
Completely signed
petitions
should be turned in to the Student
Council box, number 1246, on or
before 4 pm, Monday, April 25.
Candidates will then be announced
and the elections will be called.

Undergraduates
Give Bowman Gift
Undergraduates will present a
mahogany electric clock to President Emeritus Isaiah Bowman.
The gift, sponsored by class
presidents, is a Seth Thomas
mantlepiece. Further plans will
be announced in the class meetings, all of which will take place
next Friday at 10 am.
Sophomores will meet in Merganthaler 111 to discuss Class Day
and the class weekend. Seniors'
meeting, to be held in an as yet
undisclosed place, will be concerned with Class Day and a financial
report from the 49ar dance.
Freshmen will meet in Remsen
1 to discuss Class Day and coming plans, while the juniors will
discuss spring functions and Class
day in the Great hall of Levering.

Hopkins Library
Something new in the way or
magazines, called Our Nation's'
Heritage will be displayed this
week in the main reading room
of the Johns Hopkins University
Library.
The magazine, a gift of Charles
Garland of the University Board
of Trustees, will be published in
book form six times a year.
Abounding in colorful pictures
and first rate photography attempts to present "the American
way of life" in a pictorial manner.
The publication, according to the
publishers, the B C Forbes Company, is trying to convey "in a
dramatic, graphic way a wider
knowledge of all the elements
which have made and make our
nation; to give a picture of the
heritage .. . in a manner that will
have the greatest appeal to the
most Americans."

Price Day Speaks Before
_MC On British Empire

Third Sedar

Price Day, informal and reserved, the author of a series of
articles in The Sun on modern
imperialism and field correspondent during World War II, was
guest speaker at the International
Relations Club last Friday.
In his discussion of the changing British Empire, Mr Day began with the Indian situation.
He observed that India, though
a constitutional republic with no
allegiance to the Crown, still
wishes to remain in some association with the Commonwealth. And
Britain necessarily wishes to retain connections with India.
Has Been Burden
India, Mr Day mentioned, had
been an economic burden for years,
but from the security point of
view Britain's loss had been "terrific." From the political standpoint, now, India has the potential
power to lead an entire Southern
Asiatic bloc.
Britain must now set up some
formal relationship with its dominions. This, explained Mr Day,
reflects a change in Britain's imperial status.
Australia Industrializing
Australia, he continued, is industrializing, with hopes toward
establishing large trade areas in
, Asia. This immediately changes
the mercantile position of Britain
which previously functioned as
the middle man for Australian resources.
New Zealand, on the other hand,
Is the "closest" to her mother
country in the sense of exports.

member of the class of '49 announced his candidacy.
If student government at the Hopkins is to emerge from the
relative inertia and insignficance of its current functions on the
campus, it must attract students interested in the experience to be
gained from practicing, and at -the same time performing, the

students were reminded of a rich musical tradition that is characteristicly fertile.

Fitting Climax. Found
In Verdi's Requiem
Last week's Spring Music Festival, given under the auspices of
the Baltimore Institute of Musical
Arts, found an eminently fitting
climax in the presentation of
Verdi's Requiem Mass. The work
was performed last Sunday at the
Baltimore Polytechnic Institute
under the direction of Hugo Weisgall.
It is easy to imagine how this
turbulent music might have become a vehicle for the kind of dramatic showmanship which has upon occasion been witnessed in the
case of far less worthy music at
the Lyric. But last Sunday soloists, chorus, orchestra and conductor put heart and soul and no
little ability into as stirring a
choral composition as has ever
been written.
It is to be hoped that last week's
successful enterprise will see
repetition in the years to come.

The News-Letter editor has requested me to criticise this show.
What am I to say? The editor has
placed me in the same position
that I placed Ruth when I asked
my inane question about the use
of red. I have no universals to
which I may turn, no valid books
to read stating how a work of art
should be executed. I do know,
however, what I like in the show.
Objects which I like I consider
good, and are considered good
simply because they have given
me a feeling of pleasure. Therefore I say that which gives me
pleasure is a work of art, be it
products from a cuisine, the results of concuipisence, or, in the
present instance, creations with
pigment, pencil, ink, or plastic material.
I employ the term, "work of
art", in a thoroughly subjective
manner. That which does not give
me pleasure is not a work of art.
To someone else, yes, perhaps,
it is; but that doesn't interest- me.
Apparently no particular technique was singled out by the
udges of the current show. Abract artists and realistic artists
hd entries accepted. In fact I
shuld say that ever recognizable
art", form in the various media
specified was represented. Superficially one might say that this was
the result of the criticism from
last year's show, a show which was
heavy with expressionism and surrealism. I don't think that this
s true. The judges only expressed catholicity of taste—a human
atstribute which too many persons
attempt to negate. Of the ninetythree accepted entries, I liked the
following:
